"Oops, your tab just crashed" -> "Reload" -> "Just ooone more thing before we start" -> "Restart firefox"

At that point, I don't care about the severity of the bugs fixed, I just want to continue my browsing session, i LITERALLY just want to read what's in that one tab, but no.. that's the point, always this point, where I am in a flow, and context matters, that my beloved browser will chose to tear me out of it.. Sometimes, I'll just simply stop opening new tabs for a while, while reading what's on the ones already open..

Come one mozilla! Stop playing around with burger menus and skins and make an actually useful change for once! Make firefox politely notify me that an update is available and will be in effect next time I restart the browser, POLITELY! and then continue functioning.
stories.title: Tell HN: If I could chose one new Firefox feature, it would be this
The drone operators who halted Russian convoy headed for Kyiv
WebAssembly in My Browser Desktop Environment
Troy Kotsur makes history as the first deaf man to win an acting Oscar

stories.text:
Many years ago, I remember watching a tech talk from Gov.uk about how they design their websites. The general thrust of this talk was that, as a government service they had to be accessible to literally everyone in the UK. This included not just typical accessibility work, but also things like:

- They had to support positively ancient browsers like IE6 far longer than the rest of the internet, because some people had no choice of computing device, and the government had to serve them anyway.

- The people looking for information on Gov.uk usually aren't at their best or sharpest: they're usually stressed because they're in some kind of legal or health issue they're desperately looking to resolve, and the site had to accommodate for that with clear and understandable navigation.

- They ran user studies on usability and found that fancy date pickers tended to confuse people, and that it was far easier to just let people type dates with their keyboard. I think there were some other design notes in this vein throughout the talk.

Basically the whole thing was contrasting their approach with the typical, flashy, "cutting-edge" web development of the time. It ended (naturally) with a call for developers to apply to work there.

Try as I might I haven't been able to find this talk again. Does anyone know what this talk might be or where I might be able to find it?
stories.title: Ask HN: Looking for a Tech Talk from Gov.uk
